pros: Great people for the most part

pros: Best staff (when fully staffed), easy to work with MD's.
cons: Its a walk in clinic, so it gets super busy!

pros: Great experience with lower -mid level managers, but this is probably unit specific and about the same at any other hospital. On-campus parking for night shift. Infectious disease units were issued daily hospital scrubs. The unit I worked on had a very supportive RN and CNA team & no bullying, lateral violence, etc. (that I saw or heard first hand- or heard about).
cons: Overnight, on-call providers were sometimes difficult to reach; and frequently rude (even for RNs who kept calls to a minimum and kept communication short and to the point). No NPs/APRNs as providers. Not a MAGNET hospital. Often short-staffed and sometimes potentially dangerous RN assignments. Floating RNs from other units often given least-wanted assignments, and no unit routine reference. No access to hospital/unit procedures for reference. Off-site parking for day shift; no safe transport, or escort, to/from parking lot (even after dark &/or before sunrise). Skipping meal/break periods was (at best) the norm, and (at worst) expected.

pros: Leadership in my department was great! Seemed to care about the staff.
cons: PTO was okay but I didn’t like that you couldn’t use your sick time until you had used 24 consecutive hours of PTO. Your holidays also come out of your PTO bank.

pros: Beautiful hospital with staff that genuinely care for its patients. Good place to gain experience

pros: Some managers make working for them a pleasure
cons: Needs to improve pay to match competitors

pros: 401k with matching Insurance premium paid
cons: Unreasonable workload Culture of working off the clock to meet productivity

pros: Live in paradise but for a cost
cons: Toxic work environment. Nepotism very heavily in the hospital system. Favoritism in all departments. Wilcox CEO makes it known that if you don’t like working there then good luck trying to find other healthcare employment on the island. Pay does not match cost of living. No work live balance, especially if you have to take call. Very short staffed so be prepared to be told you have to take more call.

pros: HPH is a good company.

Management in recruiting department is horrible. Manager is not supportive, not approachable, can’t rely on her to call me back when I need help (work remotely from home). No one does anything about it. 

Director is egotistical, yells and very unprofessional. Makes all the workers feel like they are nothing. 

The manager and director has their favorites. If you are on their good side, special treatment for those and for the others we just get treated poorly.

Things should be conducted for what make sense and what is best for the department, not what is best for the individual or what they feel their entitled too. pros: Hawaii Pacific Health is a growing organization. The facilities and amenities used for patient care are of good quality. Many staff have worked for the organization for greater than five years. More staff stay with this organization than I have seen at other hospitals in large cities. Culture of safety was respected and active from a clinical perspective. Many opportunities to grow within the organization.
cons: During the COVID-19 pandemic there were times when clinical staff did not feel supported with appropriate protective equipment. If staff became infected with COVID-19 it was not clearly explained if they would be covered by workers compensation. These concerns were very specific to the pandemic, however.

review_title: Employees get the blame for Physician
pros: The pay is great and Benefits.
cons: You are not allowed time off for your own personal health. You have to train new employees who have a higher title than you with no compensation, your are sent to work in offices where your not qualified. Management will tell your not allowed to have a full lunch and there are no breaks for Nursing crew. I was train by KMC in Lihue. After 8 yrs. I resined to attend school . I have been reapplying and wAs told I'm not qualified. ( worked in the Float pool) Now Unqualified MA's are using you as ginnie pigs. I was told after giving my notice that if I didn't give a 3 week notice that they would make sure I could never work a cross the island chain.  There a lot of prejudice. Many physicians are having affairs with there nurses. The married physicians have there wife's apply under there married name  and work in the same office, OR. There is no discretion .

review_title: Great company but needs to train and monitor its managers better.
pros: Great mission!  Filled with dedicated, passionate people who really care about their work.  Good salaries and benefits help make the jobs even more rewarding.
cons: Many managers seem more concerned about managing up than taking care of employees.  The drive for meeting goals for bonuses often takes people off the right path.  Some managers are terrible, but their higher ups only see the good.  Speaking up is difficult without retaliation in some departments, even with the tools available.

pros: Very proud to work for Pali Momi Medical Center Emergency Department. The doctors & providers are so amazing, compassionate and patient-focused. As a very experienced RN, I find the doctors respectful and attentive, especially when Im advocating for my patients, the doctors are always on board. What a great place. When I submit ideas to the Administration, they are always receptive and enthusiastic about them and always give feedback.  The corporate culture embraces local values of love, caring, unity, Aloha, and the CEO and corporation display a deep respect for patients, staff and the local community. This corporation remains true to its values.
cons: Would love it if HPH had permanent, part-time positions for nurses.

review_title: A four hospital system in beautiful Hawaii
pros: Best teamwork I have ever experienced from environmental service, nursing, lab technicians, security and among units.  Great hospital system to work in with where you know most people name ( at Pali Momi) where delivery of safe, quality patient is a commitment by all and not just a catch phrase.
cons: Must get employed in any role to get foot inside the door. Most hiring is done from within the organizations which has its pros and cons.

review_title: Went from great to not so great/CRNA
job_title: Certified Registered Nurse Anesthetist in Honolulu, HI
pros: I used to be a staff CRNA at Straub (the facility that is a part of Hawaii Pacific Health, advertising this job) along with about 15 other CRNAs.  A new department chairman was hired and had a vision for an all MD anesthesia department; made life miserable and all CRNAs eventually quit.  That individual is no longer the chairman and the interim chairman is trying to change the culture.
cons: The upper management and surgeons supported the new anesthesia department chair's tactics of  creating a miserable work environment ultimately leading to all the CRNAs quitting.  It was a super micromanaged work environment; CRNAs do NOT have privileges for lines and regional.  This facility is slightly backwards regarding their view on CRNA practice.

pros: I loved my coworkers. Pretty much everyone was fun to work with and team players. It's a great hospital that really cares about the patients. I would recommend my family be treated at this hospital.
cons: Budget issues make them schedule floors short, esp nurse aides. Once RN new grad academy starts, the CNAs get taken and then we're short in the floor again. Happens twice a year. Bc staffing is short, schedules are rigid. Not too many to switch shifts with. It takes forever to get preference for weekends off. Vacations need to be bid for at the beginning of the year for the entire year.

review_title: Overall, a great place to work.
pros: The organization is forward-thinking and doing great things for Hawai‘i communities.Executive leadership is great and the senior management team runs lean.
cons: Middle management is not so great. You are expected to wear many hats in your role and stakes are ALWAYS high. You are expected perform many tasks without much training.

review_title: HPH takes care of their employees, and the staff is very family oriented.
pros: Good benefits with regards to PTO accruement, retirement and pension plans. They support education opportunities and advancement. HPH affords state-of-the-art equipment which ultimately supports patient care.
cons: Can’t really think of a “negative” to write here. Of course not all days are sunshine and roses, but for the most part I remain grateful for my job and fellow staff.

pros: You gain great experience in tier 1 IT that will help you should you (and you definitely should) go to another company.
cons: Alot of office politics and bullying. Management cares more about perception than reality. Management and BAs often are clueless.

job_title: IT Terminus Support in Honolulu, HI
pros:
*The IT Department has two main locations. The first office is located in the heart of downtown Honolulu and second office is located South of Honolulu (near Ward & Beretania).
*Co-workers that turn into friends = bonus
*Medical benefits are wonderful
*Office luncheon parties was always a blast! {note: second office ONLY}
*Tech Services,Enterprise, is an awesome team.
cons:
*Parking is expensive. Lack of parking stalls in the area. No options from company. Should take suggestions from neighboring hospital (Queen's) who provide shuttling parking service for their employee's.

*Lack of strong leadership (unethical and narcissistic)

review_title: If you don't have a job, you have nothing to lose... But BEWARE do not leave your current job for a job with HPH!!!
pros:
Pros? Well, they pay well... That was the deciding factor in leaving my long term job to work there, a $10/hr increase in salary..... 

BIGGEST MISTAKE OF MY CAREER!
cons:
BEWARE... BAIT AND SWITCH! 

One early Monday morning interview with the DIRECTOR of IT for HPH, (who advised I would be called in for a second, then a third interview.).  

I went to work at my full time job. The Recruiter who set up interview called me within 2 hours of the initial interview, and said I got the job. She said she had sent dozens of candidates over and none of them were successful, that the response from the interview with the director was amazing, and he wanted me to start immediately, (No second interview.) Promised a full time position, they condition the offer on being able to start with ONLY ONE DAYS NOTICE to current employer. (As told to me by my recruiter.) I responded that I was obligated to give current job 2 weeks notice, as I would for any job; recruiter passed message along and then responded that they conditioned the offer on being able to start on that Wednesday. (Red flag!) 

It was a $10 an hour pay increase! So I took the risk. 

First day, I was then informed it was temp position, (by the temp agency who referred me for the interview). I was assured by the director of HPH however, that it was just a technicality and a direct hire was practically guaranteed. (However I was introduced and referred to as a contractor for the length of my employ. )

Job duration was 4 months, lasted exactly the span of a big project they were implementing! (How coincidental!!) 

I was then informed that I did an excellent job! Helped them complete the project ahead of schedule! Thank you for my services, now that the huge project was completed the workload no longer necessitated a contractor... (Coincidentally it was the last day of their fiscal budget.) 

I left an had an excellent full time, long term position for this endeavor, and I was ineligible for rehire back at the old company due to "insufficient notice"... (It is my fault because I took the risk, but there should be something to be said about the principle of good faith.... )

Warning: this was for an ancillary support staff position. Don't know how they treat their medical staff. I do know that the environment is COLD and CORPORATE. 

Impulsive, reckless disregard for good faith. They do not keep their word, nor do they care about ancillary damage (that doesn't affect their deadlines). The previous hospital system I worked in was full of warmth, kindness, and the Aloha Spirit. 

If you are out of work, you have nothing to lose. But do not leave any full time position for a position here, if you take anything from my story.

review_title: Great place to work, great mission! Very fulfilling and meaningful work
pros: We get to help the community. Great leadership and fiscal accountability. Employee engagement is a focus so they truly emphasize programs that empower and appreciate employees.
cons: Lots of work, sometimes understaffed with tight deadlines to meet; can be stressful but it's getting better and always helps to be inspired and motivated by all of the stories of the patients who have benefited from our care.

review_title: Ok as a whole but each department needs help
